Articles: {"abstract": "Royal Dutch Shell is dangling the prospect of a 15 percent-plus bump in its offer to buy oil patch subsidiary Shell Canada for C$7.7 billion ($6.6 billion), if minority shareholders agree to support its takeover bid, The Globe and Mail reported. Apparently frustrated in its attempts to drum up interest in a 40-Canadian-dollars -a-share offer made in October, and fearing a nasty takeover battle, Royal Dutch has been quietly meeting with the biggest shareholders in its Calgary-based offspring in recent weeks, the report said. {"abstract": "After an earlier offer received a cool reception from minority shareholders, Royal Dutch Shell increased its bid for the portion of Shell Canada it does not own to 45 Canadian dollars ($38.10) a share from 40 Canadian dollars. The new offer values the 22 percent of Shell Canada not held by the parent company at 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion). About 150,000 barrels of Shell Canada\u2019s daily production of 230,000 barrels comes from oil sands projects in Alberta rather than conventional sources. When it made its opening bid in October, Royal Dutch Shell said that full control of Shell Canada would allow it to increase its reported reserves. An accounting problem forced the parent company to lower its reserve levels in 2004. The higher bid still may face difficulty since some Canadian fund managers have said recently that they are looking for a price near 50 Canadian dollars a share.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/24/business/worldbusiness/24fobriefs-BIDFORSHELLC_BRF.html", "snippet": "After an earlier offer received a cool reception from minority shareholders, Royal Dutch Shell increased its bid for the portion of Shell Canada it does not own to 45 Canadian dollars ($38.10) a share from 40 Canadian dollars. {"abstract": "Shell expects to resume oil production in Nigeria within five to six months after shutting down operations because of militant violence.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/05/business/worldbusiness/05shell.html", "snippet": "Shell expects to resume oil production in Nigeria within five to six months after shutting down operations because of militant violence.", "lead_paragraph": "LAGOS, Nigeria, April 4 \u2014 A year after being forced to shut more than half of its oil operations in Nigeria because of militant violence, Royal Dutch Shell says that it has reached an agreement with local communities allowing it to return safely to the Niger Delta and that it expects to resume full production within five to six months.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "1", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Shell Expects Full Output From Nigeria", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Shell Expects Full Output From Nigeria", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Royal Dutch/Shell Group", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Politics and Government", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Nigeria", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2007-04-05T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "World Business", "byline": {"original": "By Jad Mouawad", "person": [{"firstname": "Jad", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Mouawad", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/ad71b34c-0613-53f2-9290-2ce4c1f44bb5", "word_count": 989, "uri": "nyt://article/ad71b34c-0613-53f2-9290-2ce4c1f44bb5"}

{"abstract": "Royal Dutch Shell and Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, agreed to explore possibilities to work together to develop oil fields and market gasoline and other petroleum products worldwide. While short on specifics, it suggested Shell was still seeking opportunities in Russia despite being forced last fall to sell a controlling stake in its Sakhalin II development to Gazprom, another Russian state company, at a low price. {"abstract": "Jeroen van der Veer deftly righted the oil major after an accounting scandal. His successor, Peter Voser, will continue the company\u2019s overhaul.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/29/business/global/29oil.html", "snippet": "Jeroen van der Veer deftly righted the oil major after an accounting scandal. His successor, Peter Voser, will continue the company\u2019s overhaul.", "lead_paragraph": "When Jeroen van der Veer took the helm of Royal Dutch Shell five years ago, the company was mired in an accounting scandal involving its reporting of oil and gas reserves, a flap that nearly ended its century-long independence. {"abstract": "Some fund managers are skeptical about fossil fuel companies as long-term investments as nations move toward tougher rules on emissions.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/12/business/international/weighing-the-risks-of-investing-in-energy-companies.html", "snippet": "Some fund managers are skeptical about fossil fuel companies as long-term investments as nations move toward tougher rules on emissions.", "lead_paragraph": "LONDON \u2014 Norway\u2019s economy is highly dependent on oil and gas production, yet the Nordic country\u2019s largest private pension fund manager, Storebrand, worries about the risks of investing in companies that extract fossil fuels. {"abstract": "In the short term, the drop in the oil prices will make it harder to get deals done. But if low prices persist, financial stress may make small players vulnerable, Fiona Maharg-Bravo of Reuters Breakingviews writes.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2015/01/02/oil-price-slump-may-spur-european-oil-and-gas-deal-making/", "snippet": "In the short term, the drop in the oil prices will make it harder to get deals done. But if low prices persist, financial stress may make small players vulnerable, Fiona Maharg-Bravo of Reuters Breakingviews writes.", "lead_paragraph": "There was $383 billion in mergers and acquisitions in the oil and gas sector last year, as of Dec. 11. Yet Europe has largely missed out: About three-quarters of the targets have been in North America, according to Thomson Reuters data. Shale has played a big role. In 2015, oil and gas bankers in Europe will get a bigger slice of the action.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type":
